channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19: What happened on 30 April
item.description: It's the last day of April, and just three new cases of Covid-19 were announced in Aotearoa - a dramatically different situation to many other countries.

item.title: Disgraced police officer who raped colleague jailed for six years
item.description: A police officer who raped his female colleague as she slept has been jailed for six years.

item.title: Youthline scrambles to make up $300k shortfall
item.description: As the economic crisis hits, the 49-year-old charity has lost key corporate sponsors, while contacts to its counsellors are through the roof. Susan Strongman reports.

item.title: PM's earrings help fledgling jewellery firm through financial downturn
item.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern's feather-earring fashion statement at a recent media briefing has seen demand for the upcycled jewellery soar.

item.title: Queenstown business owners struggle with paying rent
item.description: Small business owners won't be sleeping well as they grapple with how to pay rent, a Queenstown operator says.

item.title: As it happened: Covid-19 updates from NZ and around the world
item.description: Police have received more than 1000 complaints of people breaching the level 3 rules. See how the rest of the day's events unfolded with RNZ's live blog.

item.title: Three new cases of Covid-19 reported in New Zealand
item.description: New Zealand has reported just three new cases of Covid-19 over the past 24 hours, the 12th day in a row the increase has remained in single digits.

item.title: The wage subsidy: Your questions answered
item.description: An employment law expert and independent employment specialist answer your curly questions about the wage subsidy.

item.title: Huge demand for food parcels predicted to grow
item.description: Auckland mayor Phil Goff is expecting the demand for free food parcels to grow as the wage subsidy finishes and more people lose their jobs.

item.title: Still no date for mosque attack gunman's sentencing
item.description: There is still no date for the sentencing of the man who pleaded guilty to the 15 March mosque attacks.

item.title: Man jailed for Hastings stabbing of Bruce Wirihana
item.description: A Hawke's Bay man has been sent to jail for stabbing a neighbour over a missing packet of tobacco.

item.title: Remuera residents gagging at eel and sewage miasma
item.description: Residents in the Auckland suburb of Remuera say they're being plagued by dead eels, sewage floating down streams and smells so pungent it makes them gag.

item.title: IPCA finds sergeant indecently assaulted woman
item.description: The Independent Police Conduct Authority has found a sergeant indecently assaulted a woman during a car journey two years ago.

item.title: Nelson-Marlborough records first Covid-19 case since 9 April
item.description: Nelson-Marlborough has recorded its first new case of Covid-19 since 9 April.

item.title: Businessman draws attention to lease clause allowing rent cuts
item.description: A Taranaki business owner is warning leaseholders to read the fine print of their contracts after he was asked to pay his rent in full despite a clause in his lease allowing for a rent cut if he couldn't legally access the property.

item.title: Human Rights Commission makes 30 recommendations in report on Covid-19 response
item.description: The government's response to Covid-19 has been good, but much more could be done to ensure the Treaty and human rights are central to decisions, Human Rights Commission says.

item.title: Health reform urged as GPs call for delayed review's release
item.description: GPs calling for reform of New Zealand's health system after hard lessons learned from Covid-19 want the delayed Health and Disability System Review to be released.

item.title: Covid-19: Jobless immigrants face poverty, deportation, exploitation - immigration adviser
item.description: An immigration consultant is warning an entrenched underclass of unlawful workers will emerge unless the government provides emergency benefits to unemployed immigrants.
